conclusion: Analyze the motion of the positively charged ball under the influence of the electric field and gravity.

The image shows a small positively charged ball starting from point O with an initial velocity at an angle θ to the horizontal direction of a uniform electric field. The ball moves along a straight line, reaching its highest point. The electric field is directed to the right.
The ball is initially at point O with an initial velocity v0 at an angle θ to the electric field. The electric field exerts a force on the ball in the opposite direction of its motion.

The ball moves in a straight line under the influence of both the electric force and gravity. The electric force acts in the opposite direction of the electric field (to the left), and gravity acts vertically downward.
At the highest point A, the horizontal component of velocity is zero. The electric force is balanced by gravity, allowing the ball to momentarily stop at the highest point.
The initial electric potential energy at O is mE0v0 cosθ because the velocity has a horizontal component influenced by the electric field.
At the highest point A, the electric potential energy is zero because the ball is momentarily stationary at the peak of its trajectory.
The difference in electric potential energy is therefore mE0v0 cosθ - 0 = mE0v0 cosθ.
The difference in electric potential energy of the small ball when it reaches the highest point compared to its electric potential energy at point O is mE0v0 cosθ.
